content.description: "The thin crack on the left side of the face. Move a little left when it ends, and continue up to some interesting moves."
content.protection: R rated, plenty of natural anchors above for top-rope.
content.location: Emerald city slab, to the far left of A frame wall. Route is located 20 feet to the left of Emerald city (crack in the center of the face). Walk down is to the left via a dirt gulley.

content.description: The lower angle splitter crack immediately right of the Emerald City slab.  Begin on the boulder ledge and follow the route to the top.
"The arete to the right of Scarecrow."
content.location: Furthest right you can go on the Emerald city slab. Starts a foot or so from the edge then slowly climbs to the right onto the arete. Walk off to the left.

content.description: Follow the corner/flake up the slab.
content.location: Corner/flake directly right of Emerald City crack.

content.description: The left facing layback corner right of VeeZee. A mountain laurel marks the start. Start on the boulder ledge right of the Emerald City slab. Pitch pine at the top.

There are several ways to climb the arête on the left end of the cliff just before the stairs. For the most fun, start at a bucket on the overhanging north face. "Most climbers will agree that the Leaning Tower of Pisa is more impressive" - KN.
content.location: The far left arête on the slab to the left of Emerald City, just before the gully and staircase.

content.description: Climb past an old bolt hole on the clean(ish) face to the right of Brief Pause. Interesting and delicate climbing leads to the top. The arêtes are off.
content.location: Located on the small slab on the left end of the cliff before the stairs.

content.description:
Climb the prominent crack in the middle of the face. 

  This is probably one of the nicest finger cracks in the state.  Short, with a nice crux section.  Definitely well protected, I have done this one with just a set of stoppers.
content.protection: Protects well with a set of stoppers.  Short and sweet.

content.description:
TR'd first by Paul Meyer in 1985, then led by Nichols in 1989, I expect most climbers will emulate Paul rather than Ken.   

  The face half-way between Emerald City and Scarecrow.
The left-facing corner right of the Leaning Tower arête. A short climb with an even shorter crux.
content.protection: Led in 1981 and not given a safety rating in Ken's book, but I didn't see anywhere for pro. Recommended toprope.
content.location: Located in the center of the small slab on the left side of the cliff before the staircase.

content.description: The Emerald City slab is made up of some very short but fun routes.  The green color of the slab from the lichen give it away.  You can scramble up the low angle slab in between The Emerald City Slab and A-Frame Wall to set up a top rope or you can lead it using your C3's or smallest size TCU's.
